unit_title: Speed, Velocity, and Rate of Position Change
subject: AP Physics 1
expanded_description: Comprehensive study of velocity and speed concepts, including average and instantaneous values, vector-scalar distinction, graphical interpretations, and mathematical relationships essential for AP Physics 1 kinematics.
learning_objectives: Define and distinguish between speed and velocity
Calculate average velocity and average speed from position data
Understand instantaneous velocity as a derivative
Apply vector mathematics to velocity problems
Solve real-world problems involving velocity and speed

core_concept.principle: Velocity Fundamentals: Velocity $\vec{v}$ (vector), Speed $v$ (scalar), Average velocity $\vec{v}_{avg} = \frac{\Delta \vec{r}}{\Delta t}$, Instantaneous velocity $\vec{v} = \frac{d\vec{r}}{dt}$, Position-time graphs, Slope interpretation, Units of m/s.
core_concept.explanation: Velocity describes the rate of change of position with time and includes direction, while speed is the magnitude of velocity and is directionless. Average values consider total changes, while instantaneous values describe motion at specific moments.

image.caption: Velocity and speed relationships with position change

sections.introduction: Understanding average velocity as displacement over time interval and average speed as total distance over time interval.

key_concept.definition: Average velocity $\vec{v}_{avg}$, Average speed $v_{avg}$, Displacement $\Delta \vec{r}$, Time interval $\Delta t$, Total distance, Vector vs scalar averages, Direction consideration, Units m/s.
key_concept.context: Average velocity describes the overall rate and direction of position change, while average speed describes how fast something moves regardless of direction.

image.caption: Average velocity vs average speed concepts

classifications.value: Classification based on time interval considerations
classifications.behavior: Average velocity depends only on initial and final positions, while average speed depends on the actual path taken; both provide overall descriptions over time intervals rather than instantaneous values

examples.explanation: Computing $v_{avg} = \frac{\text{total distance}}{\Delta t}$ from path length

image.caption: Determining average speed from distance traveled

classifications.note: Average velocity $\vec{v}_{avg} = \frac{\Delta \vec{r}}{\Delta t}$; Average speed $v_{avg} = \frac{\text{total distance}}{\Delta t}$; $|\vec{v}_{avg}| \leq v_{avg}$; Equal only for straight-line motion without direction changes.

principles.statement: Average velocity and speed provide overall descriptions of motion over time intervals: Average Velocity Definition: $\vec{v}_{avg} = \frac{\Delta \vec{r}}{\Delta t} = \frac{\vec{r}_f - \vec{r}_i}{t_f - t_i}$; Vector quantity - has both magnitude and direction; Depends only on initial and final positions; Can be zero even if there was motion (round trip). Average Speed Definition: $v_{avg} = \frac{\text{total distance traveled}}{\Delta t}$; Scalar quantity - magnitude only; Always positive or zero; Depends on the actual path taken. Mathematical Relationships: In 1D: $v_{avg} = \frac{\Delta x}{\Delta t}$ (includes sign for direction); $v_{avg} = \frac{\text{total distance}}{\Delta t}$ (always positive); $|v_{avg, velocity}| \leq v_{avg, speed}$. Physical Interpretation: Average velocity: overall rate and direction of position change; Average speed: how fast something moved overall; Different purposes and interpretations. Special Cases: Straight-line motion without reversal: $|\vec{v}_{avg}| = v_{avg}$; Round trip to start: $\vec{v}_{avg} = 0$, $v_{avg} > 0$; Curved paths: $|\vec{v}_{avg}| < v_{avg}$. Units and Dimensions: Both have units of m/s (SI); Velocity includes direction information; Speed is just a number with units. Graphical Interpretation: On position-time graph: average velocity = slope of chord between two points; Average speed = total path length on graph divided by time. Practical Calculations: For multi-segment trips: calculate total displacement for velocity; Calculate total distance for speed; Use consistent time units.
principles.application: Calculate average velocity from position data. Compute average speed from distance information. Distinguish between vector and scalar averages. Interpret average values physically. Solve multi-segment motion problems. Recognize when averages are equal.
principles.example: Walk 3 m east in 2 s, then 4 m north in 3 s: $\vec{v}_{avg} = \frac{5\text{ m northeast}}{5\text{ s}} = 1\text{ m/s northeast}$, $v_{avg} = \frac{7\text{ m}}{5\text{ s}} = 1.4\text{ m/s}$.
principles.analogy: Like the difference between your net relocation rate (average velocity - straight-line rate and direction to final position) versus your actual travel pace (average speed - how fast you were moving regardless of path); if you wander around but end up near where you started, your average velocity is small while your average speed reflects all your movement

image.caption: Principles of average velocity and speed

worked_examples.title: Average Velocity and Speed Calculations
worked_examples.problem: A car travels 8 km east in 0.2 h, then 6 km west in 0.3 h. Find: (a) Average velocity, (b) Average speed.

step_by_step.explanation: Let east be positive direction. Start at $x = 0$.
After first segment: $x = +8\text{ km}$; After second segment: $x = +8 - 6 = +2\text{ km}$
$\Delta x = x_f - x_i = 2 - 0 = +2\text{ km}$ (east)
$v_{avg} = \frac{\Delta x}{\Delta t} = \frac{+2\text{ km}}{0.5\text{ h}} = +4\text{ km/h}$ (east)
Distance = $8 + 6 = 14\text{ km}$
$v_{avg, speed} = \frac{14\text{ km}}{0.5\text{ h}} = 28\text{ km/h}$
Car ended 2 km east of start (average velocity eastward) but traveled 14 km total (higher average speed)

worked_examples.final_answer: (a) Average velocity = $+4\text{ km/h}$ (east), (b) Average speed = $28\text{ km/h}$. Demonstrates $|\vec{v}_{avg}| < v_{avg}$ for motion with reversal.

worked_examples.title: Multi-Segment Motion Analysis
worked_examples.problem: A robot moves: 2 m north in 4 s, 3 m east in 6 s, then 1 m south in 2 s. Find average velocity and speed.

step_by_step.explanation: Let north be $+y$, east be $+x$. Start at origin $(0, 0)$.
After move 1: $(0, 2)$ m; After move 2: $(3, 2)$ m; After move 3: $(3, 1)$ m
$\Delta t = 4 + 6 + 2 = 12\text{ s}$
$\vec{v}_{avg} = \frac{(3, 1)}{12} = (0.25, 0.0833)\text{ m/s}$; Magnitude = $\sqrt{0.25^2 + 0.0833^2} = 0.264\text{ m/s}$; Direction = $\arctan(0.0833/0.25) = 18.4^\circ$ north of east
Distance = $2 + 3 + 1 = 6\text{ m}$
$v_{avg} = \frac{6\text{ m}}{12\text{ s}} = 0.5\text{ m/s}$

worked_examples.final_answer: Average velocity = $0.264\text{ m/s}$ at $18.4^\circ$ north of east, Average speed = $0.5\text{ m/s}$. Shows vector average smaller than scalar average.

sections.introduction: Understanding instantaneous velocity as the derivative of position and instantaneous speed as its magnitude, describing motion at specific instants.

key_concept.definition: Instantaneous velocity $\vec{v} = \frac{d\vec{r}}{dt}$, Instantaneous speed $v = |\vec{v}|$, Derivative concept, Tangent slope, Limit process, Momentary motion, Position-time graph slope, Calculus foundation.
key_concept.context: Instantaneous velocity describes how fast and in what direction an object is moving at a specific moment, obtained as the derivative of position with respect to time.

image.caption: Instantaneous velocity as derivative of position

classifications.value: Classification based on momentary motion descriptions
classifications.behavior: Instantaneous values describe motion at specific instants rather than over intervals, requiring calculus concepts or graphical analysis of slopes; they provide detailed moment-by-motion information

examples.explanation: Finding instantaneous velocity as slope of tangent to position-time curve

image.caption: Instantaneous velocity from position-time graph slope

classifications.note: Instantaneous velocity $\vec{v} = \lim_{\Delta t \to 0} \frac{\Delta \vec{r}}{\Delta t} = \frac{d\vec{r}}{dt}$; Instantaneous speed $v = |\vec{v}|$; On position-time graph: velocity = slope of tangent line.

principles.statement: Instantaneous velocity and speed describe motion at specific moments with precise mathematical definitions: Instantaneous Velocity Definition: $\vec{v} = \lim_{\Delta t \to 0} \frac{\Delta \vec{r}}{\Delta t} = \frac{d\vec{r}}{dt}$; The derivative of position with respect to time; Vector quantity - has both magnitude and direction; Describes momentary motion completely. Instantaneous Speed Definition: $v = |\vec{v}|$; The magnitude of instantaneous velocity; Scalar quantity - magnitude only; Always positive or zero. Graphical Interpretation: On position-time graph: instantaneous velocity = slope of tangent line at specific point; Steeper slope = greater speed; Positive slope = positive direction; Negative slope = negative direction. Physical Significance: Instantaneous velocity: how fast and what direction RIGHT NOW; Instantaneous speed: how fast RIGHT NOW (speedometer reading); More detailed than average values. Calculus Foundation: For position function $x(t)$: $v(t) = \frac{dx}{dt}$; Requires understanding of derivatives; In AP Physics 1: conceptual and graphical emphasis. Relationship to Average Velocity: As $\Delta t \to 0$, average velocity $\to$ instantaneous velocity; Average velocity over very small interval approximates instantaneous velocity. Practical Determination: From motion sensors and video analysis; From position-time graph tangent slopes; From algebraic differentiation of position functions. Special Cases: Constant velocity: instantaneous velocity = average velocity; Changing velocity: instantaneous values vary with time.
principles.application: Determine instantaneous velocity graphically. Calculate derivatives for simple functions. Interpret tangent slopes on graphs. Distinguish instantaneous from average values. Solve problems using instantaneous concepts. Understand speedometer readings.
principles.example: Car moving with $x(t) = 2t^2$: $v(t) = \frac{dx}{dt} = 4t$; At $t = 3\text{ s}$, $v = 12\text{ m/s}$; Speed = $12\text{ m/s}$.
principles.analogy: Like a car's speedometer - it shows your instantaneous speed (how fast you're going RIGHT NOW), while instantaneous velocity would also include your direction; this is different from your trip computer showing average speed for the entire journey

image.caption: Principles of instantaneous velocity and speed

worked_examples.title: Graphical Instantaneous Velocity
worked_examples.problem: A position-time graph shows a curve. At point where tangent has slope: rises 4 m in 2 s. Find instantaneous velocity.

step_by_step.explanation: Instantaneous velocity = slope of tangent line to position-time curve
Slope = $\frac{\Delta y}{\Delta x} = \frac{4\text{ m}}{2\text{ s}} = 2\text{ m/s}$
Positive slope means positive velocity (direction depends on coordinate system)
Instantaneous velocity = $+2\text{ m/s}$
Speed = $|2\text{ m/s}| = 2\text{ m/s}$ (same magnitude since positive)

worked_examples.final_answer: Instantaneous velocity = $+2\text{ m/s}$, Instantaneous speed = $2\text{ m/s}$. Demonstrates graphical determination of instantaneous values.

worked_examples.title: Calculus-Based Instantaneous Velocity
worked_examples.problem: Object moves with position $x(t) = 3t^2 + 2t + 1$ (m). Find instantaneous velocity at $t = 2\text{ s}$.

step_by_step.explanation: $v(t) = \frac{dx}{dt} = \frac{d}{dt}(3t^2 + 2t + 1) = 6t + 2$
At exactly $t = 2\text{ s}$, object has instantaneous velocity $14\text{ m/s}$
Speed = $|14\text{ m/s}| = 14\text{ m/s}$ (positive)

worked_examples.final_answer: Instantaneous velocity at $t = 2\text{ s}$ is $14\text{ m/s}$, speed is $14\text{ m/s}$. Shows calculus application.

sections.introduction: Interpreting velocity from position-time graphs and applying velocity concepts to real-world motion scenarios.

key_concept.definition: Position-time graphs, Slope analysis, Tangent lines, Motion diagrams, Real-world applications, Sports analysis, Transportation physics, Motion interpretation.
key_concept.context: Position-time graphs provide visual representations of motion where slopes represent velocities, enabling intuitive understanding of motion patterns and changes.

classifications.value: Classification based on graphical interpretation approaches
classifications.behavior: Different graphical features correspond to specific motion characteristics: slope indicates velocity, slope sign indicates direction, curvature indicates acceleration; together they provide complete motion description

examples.explanation: Analyzing motion characteristics from position-time graph features
Applying velocity concepts to practical motion scenarios

classifications.note: Graph features: Straight line = constant velocity; Curved line = changing velocity; Positive slope = positive velocity; Negative slope = negative velocity; Zero slope = zero velocity (stopped).

principles.statement: Position-time graphs and motion diagrams provide powerful tools for understanding velocity in practical contexts: Position-Time Graph Features: Slope = velocity; Steepness = speed; Sign = direction; Straight line = constant velocity; Curved line = changing velocity; Horizontal line = zero velocity. Slope Interpretation: Positive slope: moving in positive direction; Negative slope: moving in negative direction; Zero slope: stationary; Increasing slope: speeding up in positive direction; Decreasing slope: slowing down or speeding up in negative direction. Motion Diagrams: Series of position dots at equal time intervals; Spacing indicates speed; Changing spacing indicates acceleration; Direction shows velocity direction. Real-World Applications: Sports: analyzing athlete motion, sprint speeds; Transportation: vehicle speeds, traffic flow; Physics experiments: motion sensor data analysis; Everyday life: walking, running speeds. Speed Estimation Techniques: From video analysis: position changes between frames; From motion sensors: ultrasonic or infrared detection; From measured distances and times. Velocity in Different Contexts: Linear motion: 1D velocity (with sign); Planar motion: 2D velocity vector; Circular motion: tangential speed with changing direction. Common Motion Patterns: Constant velocity: equal spacing in motion diagrams; Acceleration: changing spacing; Oscillation: back-and-forth motion with velocity sign changes. Practical Problem Solving: Given position-time data, calculate velocities; Given velocity information, predict positions; Use graphs to visualize motion patterns.
principles.application: Interpret position-time graphs. Construct motion diagrams. Calculate velocities from graphical data. Apply velocity concepts to real scenarios. Solve transportation and sports problems. Use graphical analysis for motion prediction.
principles.example: Car trip: position-time graph shows straight segment (constant velocity on highway), curved segment (acceleration on ramp), horizontal segment (stopped at light).
principles.analogy: Like reading a story through pictures - the position-time graph tells the 'story' of motion: where the object was (vertical position), when it was there (horizontal time), and how its movement changed (slope patterns), with the velocity being the 'plot' of how quickly the position changes

worked_examples.title: Position-Time Graph Analysis
worked_examples.problem: Analyze this position-time graph: Straight line from (0,0) to (4,20), then horizontal to (6,20), then straight line to (8,10). Describe the motion and find velocities.

step_by_step.explanation: Straight line from (0,0) to (4,20): slope = $\frac{20-0}{4-0} = 5\text{ m/s}$; Constant velocity $+5\text{ m/s}$
Horizontal line: slope = 0; Velocity = 0 (stationary)
Straight line from (6,20) to (8,10): slope = $\frac{10-20}{8-6} = \frac{-10}{2} = -5\text{ m/s}$; Constant velocity $-5\text{ m/s}$
Moves forward at 5 m/s for 4 s, stops for 2 s, then moves backward at 5 m/s for 2 s
Speeds: 5 m/s, 0 m/s, 5 m/s (all positive magnitudes)

worked_examples.final_answer: Segment 1: $v = +5\text{ m/s}$, Segment 2: $v = 0\text{ m/s}$, Segment 3: $v = -5\text{ m/s}$. Motion: forward → stop → backward with constant speeds when moving.

worked_examples.title: Real-World Velocity Problem
worked_examples.problem: A sprinter runs 100 m in 10 s. (a) Find average speed. (b) If they start from rest and reach 12 m/s at finish, estimate average acceleration. (c) Compare start and finish instantaneous speeds.

step_by_step.explanation: $v_{avg} = \frac{100\text{ m}}{10\text{ s}} = 10\text{ m/s}$

Assuming constant acceleration: $v_{avg} = \frac{v_i + v_f}{2} = \frac{0 + 12}{2} = 6\text{ m/s}$, but this doesn't match 10 m/s, so acceleration not constant. For estimation: $a_{avg} = \frac{\Delta v}{\Delta t} = \frac{12}{10} = 1.2\text{ m/s}^2$
Start: instantaneous speed = 0 m/s; Finish: instantaneous speed = 12 m/s
Average speed (10 m/s) is between start and finish instantaneous speeds; Sprinter accelerates throughout race
World-class sprinters have similar patterns: start from rest, accelerate through race, reach maximum speed near finish

worked_examples.final_answer: (a) Average speed = $10\text{ m/s}$, (b) Average acceleration ≈ $1.2\text{ m/s}^2$, (c) Instantaneous speeds: start 0 m/s, finish 12 m/s. Shows relationships between different velocity concepts.

common_misconceptions: Thinking velocity and speed are the same
Believing average speed is always the average of instantaneous speeds
Confusing slope on position-time graph with position value
Thinking negative velocity means slowing down
Believing instantaneous velocity requires calculus in all cases
summary: Velocity describes the rate of position change with direction ($\vec{v} = \frac{d\vec{r}}{dt}$), while speed is its magnitude ($v = |\vec{v}|$). Average values consider total changes over time intervals, while instantaneous values describe motion at specific moments. Position-time graphs provide visual representations where slopes indicate velocities. These fundamental concepts form the basis for kinematics analysis in AP Physics 1, with applications ranging from sports performance to transportation physics.
